verses.text: Bezalel and Oholiab, and every craftsman whom the LORD had given skill and ability, to know how to do all the work for the service of the sanctuary, shall do according to all that the LORD has commanded.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering, emphasizing the God-given skill for sanctuary work.

verses.text: And Moses called Bezalel and Oholiab and every craftsman in whose heart the LORD had put skill, everyone whose heart moved him to come do the work.
verses.comment: Stresses voluntary service prompted by the heart.

verses.text: They received from Moses all the offerings that the Israelites had brought for the work of the sanctuary, to do it. And they kept bringing him freewill offerings every morning.
verses.comment: Clarifies continual generosity of the people.

verses.text: So all the skilled workers who were doing all the work of the sanctuary came, each from the work he was doing,
verses.comment: “Skilled workers” is a literal rendering of the Hebrew.

verses.text: and they said to Moses, 'The people bring much more than enough for doing the work that the LORD has commanded us to do.'
verses.comment: Direct speech preserved as in the original text.

verses.text: So Moses gave a command, and they caused it to be proclaimed throughout the camp, 'Let neither man nor woman do any more work for the offering for the sanctuary.' So the people were restrained from bringing.
verses.comment: “Restrained” is a literal and clear rendering.

verses.text: For what they had was already sufficient to do all the work, and more.
verses.comment: Maintains the sense of abundance in the Hebrew.

verses.text: And every skilled worker among them made the tabernacle with ten curtains of finely twisted linen and blue, purple, and scarlet yarn; with cherubim skillfully worked into them.
verses.comment: Matches the original list of colors and materials closely.

verses.text: The length of each curtain was twenty-eight cubits, and the width of each curtain four cubits; all the curtains were the same size.
verses.comment: “Cubit” left untranslated as in most literal versions.

verses.text: He joined five curtains together, and the other five curtains he joined together.
verses.comment: Only the subject 'he' changed for modern readability.

verses.text: He made loops of blue yarn on the edge of the last curtain of the first set, and likewise he did on the edge of the last curtain in the second set.
He made fifty loops on one curtain, and fifty loops he made on the edge of the curtain in the second set; the loops were opposite one another.
He made fifty gold clasps and joined the curtains together with them, so the tabernacle became one whole.
He made curtains of goats' hair for a tent over the tabernacle; eleven such curtains he made.
The length of each curtain was thirty cubits, and the width four cubits; the eleven curtains were all the same size.
He joined five of the curtains separately and six curtains separately.
He made fifty loops on the edge of the last curtain in one set and fifty loops on the edge of the curtain in the other set.
He made fifty bronze clasps to join the tent together so it became one.
verses.comment: No change; material noted as bronze.

verses.text: He made a covering for the tent of ram skins dyed red, and a covering of fine leather above that.
verses.comment: ‘Fine leather’—the Hebrew word is uncertain; see note.

verses.text: He made the upright frames for the tabernacle out of acacia wood.
Each frame was ten cubits long and one and a half cubits wide.
Each frame had two tenons, joined one to another; he did this for all the frames of the tabernacle.
verses.comment: ‘Tenons’ are tab joints, as in most literal versions.

verses.text: He made the frames for the tabernacle: twenty frames for the south side.
He made forty silver bases to go under the twenty frames, two bases under each frame for its two tenons.
For the north side of the tabernacle he made twenty frames
and forty silver bases, two bases under each frame.
For the rear of the tabernacle, toward the west, he made six frames.
He made two frames for the corners at the rear of the tabernacle.
They were double beneath and also joined at the top, at the first ring. He did this for both of them at the two corners.
verses.comment: Clarifies join at top and bottom.

verses.text: So there were eight frames and sixteen silver bases, two bases under each frame.
He made crossbars of acacia wood: five for the frames on one side of the tabernacle,
five for the frames on the other side of the tabernacle, and five for the frames at the rear, facing west.
He made the middle crossbar to pass through the frames from end to end, halfway up.
He covered the frames with gold and made gold rings for them to hold the crossbars, and he covered the crossbars with gold.
He made the veil of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen; with cherubim woven into it by a skilled craftsman.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of colors and craftsmanship.

verses.text: He made four posts of acacia wood for it and covered them with gold; he cast four gold hooks for them, and he made four silver bases for them.
He made a screen for the entrance to the tent, of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and finely twisted linen, the work of an embroiderer;
and its five posts with their hooks. He overlaid their tops and their bands with gold, but their five bases were bronze.
verses.comment: ‘Bands’ is sometimes translated as ‘capitals’; here rendered more functionally.
